Fig. 1 N2 sorption isotherms (a) and pore size distributions (b) of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns for Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2= Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XPS Fe 2p spectra of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1= V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn). (More details are shown in Fig. S4.). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS O 1 s spectra of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 and FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 CO2-TPD profiles of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Catalytic properties of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn): (a) the ratio of BD produced through ODH and DH, (b) TOF, (c) 1-butene conversion, (d) CO2 conversion, (e) BD selectivity and (f) byproduct selectivity from 1-butene. (All catalytic data presented herein were collected at 10 min under the reaction; the long-term catalytic data was shown in Fig. S7 and the content of the produced CO and H2 was shown in Table S2.). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Catalytic activities of Fe2O3, γ-Al2O3, Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3, Fe2O3/HY, Fe2O3/MCM-41 and FeVCrOX. (More details are shown in Fig. S8.). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Relationship between the binding energy of type Ⅱ oxygen and the TOF. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Two pathways for BD synthesis on γ-Al2O3-supported Fe-based metal oxide catalysts under the atmosphere of 1-butene and CO2. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 A possible pathway of the ODH of 1-butene to BD with CO2 over Fe2O3. Graphical abstract The utilization of CO2 as a soft oxidant for the synthesis of 1,3-butadiene (BD) through the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of 1-butene is emerging as a potential technology not only because it can reduce the environmental problems caused by CO2 but also because of the abundant availability, low cost and mild oxidizing properties of CO2. However, this technology suffers from low catalytic activities due to the inherent inertness of CO2. Herein, a high-efficiency iron-based catalyst for the ODH of 1-butene with CO2 was designed and prepared from the perspective of improving the catalyst oxygen mobility, and the turnover frequency (TOF) has been improved to thrice that of the traditional Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Furthermore, the effect of the oxygen mobility in the catalysts on their catalytic activity was determined. The oxygen mobility of the catalysts played a key role in CO2 activation, which in turn facilitated the ODH reaction. The TOFs of the catalysts increased linearly with increasing oxygen mobility. In addition, the γ-Al2O3 support, especially the Lewis acid sites on its surface, was proved to be necessary for the reaction. Both the carrier and active component were required for the reaction to proceed. Based on the above results, the mechanism of the ODH of 1-butene with CO2 was proposed. Keywords 1,3-Butadiene 1-Butene CO2 Oxidative dehydrogenation Oxygen mobility 1 Introduction Over the past few decades, CO2 utilization has attracted the interest of the global chemical community due to the dramatic increase in the atmospheric CO2 level and the resulting environmental problems, such as global warming and ocean acidification [1–9]. In addition to transforming CO2 to value-added products, e.g., the synthesis of urea, formic acid, cyclic carbonates, methanol, lactone and salicylic acid, the application of CO2 as a soft oxidant is another highly attractive avenue of CO2 utilization [1,10–13]. Its abundant availability, low toxicity, low cost and mild oxidizing properties have made CO2 more attractive than other oxidants, i.e., O2, NO2 and SO2, for several reactions [1,2,14,15]. 1,3-Butadiene (BD) is one of the most important chemicals in the petrochemical industry for the production of styrene-butadiene rubber, polybutadiene rubber and acrylonitrile butadiene-styrene resin [16,17]. Among the methods of producing BD, the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of 1-butene with CO2 as a soft oxidant (Eq. 1) meets the established environmental restrictions and has gained increasing attention [18–21]. In addition to the advantages mentioned above, CO2 acts as a diluent in the ODH reaction, allowing it to not only serve as a mild oxidant but also minimize the hot spots and explosion risk better than O2 (Eq. 2) [1]. (1) CH2=CH−CH2CH3 + CO2 → CH2=CH−CH = CH2 + CO + H2O (2) CH2=CH−CH2CH3 + 1/2O2 → CH2=CH−CH = CH2 + H2O ODH of 1-butene to BD with CO2 as a soft oxidant have been conducted by Liu et al. since 2014 [18–20]. The optimal catalytic performance, with a 1-butene conversion of 80.0% and BD selectivity of 27.3%, was obtained over Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 as the catalyst with Fe2O3 loading of 20 wt.% [19]. Recently, we constructed an iron-doped ordered mesoporous alumina catalyst, and the BD rate and catalyst stability were improved to some extent compared with the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [21]. However, there was still great disparity between the reaction activity currently achievable through this synthetic route with CO2 as the oxidant and the synthetic route with O2 as the oxidant. The low catalytic activity of the current catalysts is the biggest problem as it blocks the further development and industrialization of this synthetic technique. Thus, the development of high-performance catalysts is urgently needed. The barrier to the utilization of CO2 arises from the thermodynamic stability, low reactivity and high oxidation state of CO2 [1,2]. Thus, the key to using CO2 in catalytic reactions is CO2 activation. Moreover, understanding the mechanism of the reaction plays an important role in the design of high-efficiency catalysts. The ODH of 1-butene to BD with CO2 over Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 was supposed to follow a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism [18]. In that mechanism, the lattice oxygen in the catalyst was involved in the ODH reaction of 1-butene to BD, and CO2 re-oxidized the reduced catalyst. Unfortunately, there was no experimental evidence. Nonetheless, from studies on other ODH processes with CO2 as a soft oxidant, we learned that the oxygen vacancies in bulk catalysts could abstract the oxygen from CO2 molecules, forming dissociated oxygen and CO [1,22]. The formed dissociated oxygen was responsible for hydrogen abstraction from alkanes/alkenes, and the catalyst was reduced along with the oxygen vacancy formed in this system [1,22]. Then, the formed oxygen vacancy could be re-oxidized by CO2, and the catalyst returned to its original state [1,22]. The catalytic reaction progressed through this cycle. This suggested that oxygen mobility played an important role in CO2 activation and thus was a crucial factor for determining the activity of a catalyst in this ODH reaction. Therefore, from the perspective of improving the catalyst oxygen mobility, high-activity catalysts for the ODH of 1-butene with CO2 as a soft oxidant were designed. Specifically, the oxygen mobility of the catalysts was modulated through element doping by a simple impregnation method based on the conventional Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The catalytic activity as well as the oxygen mobility of the catalysts were quantified, and the role of oxygen mobility in the reaction was investigated by establishing the quantitative relationship between the two. In addition, the role of the γ-Al2O3 support and the active component, the metal oxide, in the reaction as well as whether there was a synergistic effect between the two were also discussed to clarify the mechanism of the catalytic reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals The γ-Al2O3 was purchased from Zibo, Shandong province. HY, a zeolite, was provided by NanKai Catalyst (Tianjin, China), and MCM-41 was purchased from Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech Co., Ltd. The other reagents, including Fe(NO3)3•9H2O, NH4VO3, Cr(NO3)3•9H2O, Co(NO3)2•6H2O, Ni(NO3)2•6H2O, Cu(NO3)2•3H2O, Zn(NO3)2•6H2O, citric acid, NH4NO3 (Analytical reagent, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.), and 50% manganese nitrate aqueous solution (Tianjin Kermel Chemical Co., Ltd.), were used without further purification unless otherwise noted. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared according to the method we reported previously [23]. Atomic doping of the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was accomplished as follows. Taking the preparation of the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst doped with V as an example, γ-Al2O3 was added to 100 mL of an aqueous solution of Fe(NO3)3•9H2O and NH4VO3, and the mixture was stirred vigorously at 333 K for 4 h. Then, the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residual solid was dried at 393 K for 4 h in an oven. After calcination at 873 K for 4 h in a muffle furnace, the V-doped Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was obtained and named FeVOX/γ-Al2O3. The other doped Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were named FeM1Ox/γ-Al2O3. Herein “M1” represented Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn according to the doped element. Based on the FeVOX/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, we doped a second element into the catalyst via the method described above. That was, the second element was added to the impregnation solution at the same time as the V. These catalysts were named FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3, in which “M2” stands for Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn according to the second doping element. The theoretical weight percentage of Fe was 15%, and the designed mole ratio of Fe to the dopant was 9:1. The purchased HY was protonated via ammonia exchange twice [24]. Fe2O3/HY and Fe2O3/MCM-41 were prepared using the same impregnation method as was used to prepare Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3. Fe2O3 and FeVCrOX were prepared by a citric acid sol-gel method [25]. 2.3 Characterization ICP-OES (Prodigy XP) was conducted to measure the concentrations of Fe, V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn in the samples. Before the measurements, the samples were digested in an aqueous solution of H3PO4 and H2SO4 assisted by microwave irradiation (CEM-Discover). The textual properties of the catalysts were measured using a Quantachrome Autosorb (iQ) apparatus by nitrogen adsorption at 77 K. Before analysis, the samples were degassed at 573 K for 24 h under vacuum. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was used for calculating the specific surface areas from the isotherms. The cumulative volumes of the pores were obtained by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method using the desorption branches of the adsorption isotherms. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed using a Shimadzu MAXima_X XRD-7000 diffractometer employing nickel-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at 40 kV. Diffraction data were collected using a scanning rate of 0.02°/step in a 2θ range from 10 to 80° with a scanning time of 0.3 s/step at 40 mA. The CO2 adsorption abilities of the catalysts were examined by temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) measurements, which were made on a Chembet Pulsar TPR/TPD instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Each sample (∼50 mg) was pretreated at 823 K for 1 h in flowing He followed by CO2 adsorption at 333 K. Desorbed CO2 was monitored at a heating rate of 10 K min−1 from 348 to 873 K. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out on a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi K-Alpha system operated at a pass energy of 1486.6 eV for survey spectra with an Al KR X-ray source. The acceleration voltage was 15 kV, the power was 150 W, and the analysis area was 0.8 mm2. Possible deviations due to electric charges on the samples were corrected using the C1 s line at 284.8 eV as the internal standard. Multipak software 8.0 was used for data processing. 2.4 Catalytic test in the ODH of 1-butene with CO2 Catalytic performances were evaluated in a fixed-bed isothermal reactor ( ± 0.5 K deviation) that comprised a quartz tubular reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm. A run was initiated by loading 200 mg of catalyst (20–40 mesh) into the reactor. The reactant gas, which was made up of 1-butene and CO2 (molar ratio of 1-butene/CO2 = 1:9), was passed over the catalyst at 60 mL/min (STP, WHSV = 4.5 g/g-cat∙h). Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was heated to the reaction temperature under a N2 atmosphere, and the reaction temperature was maintained at 873 K. The reactions and side reactions are listed in Eq. 1 and Eqs. 3 − 5: (3) CH2=CH−CH2CH3 → CH2=CH−CH = CH2 + H2 (4) CH2=CH−CH2CH3 → C1 + C2 + C3 (5) CH2=CH−CH2CH3 → cis−CH3CH = CHCH3 + trans−CH3CH = CHCH3 In Eq. 4, C1, C2 and C3 represent the pyrolysis products (methane, ethane, ethene and propene). The reaction products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (GC2060, Shanghai Ruimin Instrument Co., Ltd., China) equipped with two columns: a capillary column (HT-PLOT Al2O3/S, 50 m × 0.53 mm × 25.00 μm) connected to a flame ionization detector (FID 1) for measuring methane, ethane, ethene, propene, 1-butene, trans-2-butene, cis-2-butene and BD, and a packed column (TCX) connected to a TCD for measuring H2 and separating CO2 and CO. CO2 and CO at the outlet of the packed column were detected by an FID (FID 2) equipped with a methane conversion oven (MTN-1, Shanghai Ruimin Instrument Co., Ltd., China). The error margin in the GC was 1–2%. The carbon balances of the experiments were in the range of 91–98% (as an example, the carbon balance achieved with FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3 is shown in Fig. S1). The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated from the moles of BD produced and the number of moles of active sites; the number of moles of BD produced was determined by GC, and the number of moles of the active sites was calculated using the number of moles of Fe. The turnover number (TON) and TOF were defined as follows: (6) TON = n B D n F e (7) TOF = T O N t Conversion, selectivity and the ratio of BD produced through Eq. 1 (Ratio(ODH)) or Eq. 3 (Ratio(DH)) were determined using Eqs. 8–12: (8) Conversio n 1 − butene = Mole s 1 − butene inlet − Mole s 1 − butene outlet Mole s 1 − butene inlet × 100 % (9) Conversio n C O 2 = Mole s C O 2 inlet − Mole s C O 2 outlet Mole s C O 2 inlet × 100 % (10) Selectivit y i = Moles of Componen t i Mole s 1 − butene inlet − Mole s 1 − butene outlet × 100 % (11) Rati o DH = Mole s H 2 outlet Mole s BD outlet × 100 % (12) Rati o ODH = 1 − Rati o DH × 100 % 3 Results 3.1 Oxygen mobility modulation As reported, heteroatom doping was an effective method for improving the lattice oxygen content and oxygen mobility of transition metal oxide catalysts [26–28]. Herein, based on the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, we modulated the catalyst through doping with one or two transition metals that had atomic radii similar to that of Fe (V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu and Zn) into the Fe2O3. The content of Fe and the doping elements in the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) catalysts were determined by ICP, and the results are shown in Table 1 . It was shown that the actual loadings of Fe in all these 14 catalysts were comparable (∼ 11%), and the mole ratio of Fe to the dopant in all these samples was approximately 9:1. The textures of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) were characterized by N2 adsorption, and the N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distributions are shown in Fig. 1 . All the samples possessed type-IV isotherms with H2-type of hysteresis loops, which are typical of “ink bottle”-shaped mesopores structures [29]. Except for the samples doped with two elements (FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3), which showed two hole distributions, the textures of the samples remained approximately the same, illustrating that doping has little effect on the overall texture of the catalysts. The textural parameters of these samples are presented in Table 1. When doped with heteroatoms, the specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of the catalysts decreased to different extents, suggesting that the heteroatoms entered into the pore channels of γ-Al2O3 without blocking the pores. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) catalysts. All samples exhibited characteristic peaks for γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS Card No. 10-0425) and peaks associated with α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles (JCPDS Card No. 33-0664). This suggested that after calcination, the Fe species loaded on the surface of γ-Al2O3 were in the form of α-Fe2O3. After doping with only Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn or Cr, the crystalline structures of the catalysts (FeMnOX/γ-Al2O3, FeCoOX/γ-Al2O3, FeNiOX/γ-Al2O3, FeCuOX/γ-Al2O3, FeZnOX/γ-Al2O3, FeCrOX/γ-Al2O3) remained the same as that of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3. While for the sample doped with only V, i.e., FeVOX/γ-Al2O3, characteristic peaks for Fe0.716V1.284O4 (JCPDS Card No. 32-0467) and V2O5 (JCPDS Card No. 32-0206, poor catalytic activity in the ODH of 1-butene with CO2, as shown in Table S1) were observed at 31.443°, 36.238°, 53.472°, and 60.245°, which were further confirmed by UV–vis spectra (Fig. S2) [30]. To determine if the FeVOX/γ-Al2O3 sample was a special case, FeVOX/γ-Al2O3 was doped with a second element. The peaks associated with Fe0.716V1.284O4 and V2O5 also appeared in the patterns of the FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3, FeVMnOX/γ-Al2O3, FeVCoOX/γ-Al2O3, FeVNiOX/γ-Al2O3, FeVCuOX/γ-Al2O3 and FeVZnOX/γ-Al2O3 samples. The formation of an iron-vanadium oxide proved that the V dopant can interacted with Fe. There were two possible reasons why no characteristic peaks for Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn or Cr species appeared in the patterns of these catalysts. One possibility was that the Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn or Cr species were highly dispersed [31]. The other possibility was that the characteristic peaks for the iron oxide doped with the relevant element were masked by the peaks associated with α-Fe2O3. Besides new characteristic peaks appeared, the peaks respected for α-Fe2O3 weakened greatly and also their half-peak width widened after Cr and V doping, indicating the improvement of the dispersion of the catalysts. To understand the interaction between Fe and the dopants in the FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) catalysts, these catalysts as well as Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 were characterized by XPS. The XPS spectra of the Fe 2p region are shown in Fig. 3 . After doping with Cr or V, the binding energy of Fe 2p increased (in which doping effect has played an imported role, since the forming of new crystalline phase only cannot contribute to the high BE of Fe 2p, shown in Fig. S3), illustrating the increased electron density around Fe [32]. This shows the electron transfer from Cr/V to Fe due to the interaction between Fe and Cr/V, which is in accordance with the XRD results shown in Fig. 2. Since CO2 is considered a poor electron donor and good electron acceptor, accepting an electron into its antibonding p orbital could cause the molecule to bend, which is an essential step for CO2 activation [2]. Thus, the increase in the electron density around Fe could contribute to the activation of CO2 in the catalytic cycle. The O 1 s spectra obtained by XPS were investigated to study the effect of heteroatom doping on the lattice oxygen content and oxygen mobility of the FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) catalysts. The corresponding O 1 s spectra of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 and FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3 are shown in Fig. 4 (the O 1 s spectra of the other 12 samples are shown in Fig. S5). As reported, deconvolution of the O 1 s spectra gave three oxygen peaks that correspond to the lattice oxygen (O I, ∼ 530.20 eV), oxygen defect/vacancies (O II, ∼ 531.50 eV), and surface-adsorbed oxygen (O III, ∼ 532.50 eV) [33,34]. The curve fitting results are shown in Table 2 . Table 2 shows that doping with V or Cr (especially V) could noticeably improve the lattice oxygen contents in the catalysts, while for single-element doping with Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn, i.e., FeMnOX/γ-Al2O3, FeCoOX/γ-Al2O3, FeNiOX/γ-Al2O3, FeCuOX/γ-Al2O3 and FeZnOX/γ-Al2O3, the lattice oxygen content decreased or remained almost unchanged compared with that of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3. Among the 14 catalysts, FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3 possessed the highest lattice oxygen content (59.4%), which was much higher than that of the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (37.7%). The binding energy of O 1 s of the metal oxide catalysts increased with decreasing valence electron density on the lattice oxygen [35,36]. This indicated that the metal–oxygen bonds in the catalysts would be weakened with increasing binding energy of O 1 s, making the transformation between lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancy more active and mobile [35,36]. In other words, higher binding energies of O 1 s corresponded to higher oxygen mobilities [35,36]. Therefore, the binding energy of O II was used as an indicator of the oxygen mobility of the catalyst in this work, which is consistent with the method reported [35,36]. Table 2 shows that the binding energies of O II for the V- and Cr-doped catalysts were higher than that of the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, while for the single element-doped samples (Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn samples), their binding energies of O II were lower. For the V-doped catalysts, besides doping effect, the shift of O II to higher binding energies may have other origins and the most obvious one was forming a different type of crystalline phase, i.e. FeVO4 mixed oxide (Fig. 2). In order to rule out this, O 1 s spectra of FeVO4 was taken, and the binding energy of O 1 s in FeVO4 was much lower than that in V-doped catalysts (Fig. S6). This demonstrated that the doping effect was the main reason for the shift of binding energy of V-doped samples. All these proved that the catalyst binding energy of O II could be improved by doping with V or Cr, which would in turn make the lattice oxygen more active and mobile. This would enhance the catalytic property of the catalysts. The CO2 adsorption abilities of the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) catalysts were measured by CO2-TPD (Fig. 5 ). It can be seen from Fig. 5 that there was only one peak at 415 K for the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. After single-element doping with Co, Cu, Mn, Ni or Zn, the intensity of this peak improved in sequence. When doping with V or Cr, the intensity of this low-temperature peak decreased, while a high-temperature peak at 685 K appeared. We attributed the peak at 415 K to the physical absorption of CO2, while the peak at 685 K was attributed to the chemisorption of CO2 [37]. This indicated that doping with V or Cr could increase the CO2 adsorption ability of the catalysts, which could thus enhance the CO2 activation ability of the catalysts. 3.2 Catalytic activities of catalysts with different oxygen mobilities The catalytic properties of the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, FeM1OX/γ-Al2O3 (M1 = V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) and FeVM2OX/γ-Al2O3 (M2 = Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn) catalysts in the catalytic ODH of 1-butene to BD using CO2 as a soft oxidant were measured (Fig. 6 ). Under catalytic conditions, BD could be formed by either ODH (Eq. 1) or DH (Eq. 3) of 1-butene [21]. Considering both of these possibilities, the ratio of BD production via ODH to DH was evaluated, and the results are shown in Fig. 6a. The proportion of the ODH path was in 84.8–90.8% range, which clearly illustrated that BD formation mainly followed Eq. 1. The TOFs of these 14 catalysts are shown in Fig. 6b. Obviously, doping with V or Cr improved the TOF of catalysts, as their TOFs were more than twice that of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3. Single doping with Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn had little influence on the TOF of the catalyst. Among these 14 catalysts, FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3 possessed the highest TOF (0.0035 molBD/molFe/s), which was more than thrice that of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 (0.0011 molBD/molFe/s). This result was consistent with the previous characterization results. The reactant conversions achieved with these 14 catalysts are presented in Fig. 6c (1-butene conversion) and Fig. 6d (CO2 conversion). After doping with V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn, the 1-butene conversion achieved with the catalysts remained basically unchanged and remained at ∼ 73.0% (Fig. 6c). However, there was a big difference in the CO2 conversions of these 14 catalysts (Fig. 6d). For the Mn-, Co-, Ni-, Cu- or Zn-doped catalysts, the CO2 conversions stayed basically the same or changed little compared with that of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3. While for the V- or Cr-doped catalysts, the CO2 conversion improved substantially compared with that of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3. In addition, FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3 possessed the highest CO2 conversion (5.6%) among all 14 catalysts. These results demonstrated that V or Cr doping could improve the CO2 conversion instead of the 1-butene conversion. The trend in the impact of heteroatom doping on the BD selectivity of the catalysts was similar to that of the CO2 conversion (Fig. 6e). Single-element doping with Mn, Co, Ni, Cu or Zn had little influence on the BD selectivity of the catalysts. While for the V- or Cr-doped samples, the BD selectivity increased substantially compared with that of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3. Most importantly, the BD selectivities of the catalysts doped with V (32.4–39.1%) were more than twice that of Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 (16.0%). Fig. 6f shows the selectivities of these catalysts for the byproducts. The results showed that the byproducts detected in these reaction mixtures were a few pyrolysis products (methane, ethane, ethene and propene) and many isomerization products (trans-2-butene and cis-2-butene), which was consistent with previously reported results. 3.3 ODH reaction over different catalysts γ-Al2O3 as an individual carrier and Fe2O3 as the active component were evaluated for BD production through the ODH of 1-butene using CO2 as a soft oxidant, as shown in Fig. 7 . BD was the target product of the reaction; therefore, the rate of BD production was considered the main parameter for evaluating the catalytic properties of these catalysts [21]. Compared with the high catalytic activity of the supported catalyst, Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, it was demonstrated that both the carrier and active component were required for the reaction to run successfully. MCM-41 and H–Y zeolite (HY), typically neutral and Bronsted acid-containing materials, were also used as supports for comparison with γ-Al2O3 (a typically Lewis acid-containing material)-supported catalyst to determine the impact of the carrier type. The results shown in Fig. 7 indicated that Lewis acid sites had a positive impact on the reaction. The small increase in activity over Fe2O3/MCM-41 demonstrated that low Fe2O3 dispersion was not the main reason for the low catalytic activity. To exclude the effect of oxygen mobility, FeVCrOX was also prepared, and it exhibited a performance similar to that of Fe2O3. But, when it was supported on γ-Al2O3, the catalyst (FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3) has shown an excellent catalytic activity. This further proved that the γ-Al2O3 support and especially the Lewis acid sites on its surface were necessary for the reaction. 4 Discussion 4.1 The role of the oxygen mobility Transition metal oxide catalysts are increasingly being used for oxidation reactions because of their good catalytic performance, which is due to their rich supply and easy recovery of lattice oxygen, known as oxygen mobility [38–40]. Usually, high oxygen mobility is beneficial for catalytic activity. Gong et al. suggested that increasing the oxygen mobility of nickel-based catalysts could overcome their drawbacks including sintering and carbon deposition and increase H2 production [25]. Dasireddy et al. proved that the high O2-storage/release in Ni-Mo/Al2O3 was beneficial for the conversion of n-butane to BD [41]. Kim et al. experimentally showed that the rates of NO oxidation over La1-XSrXCoO3 catalysts were correlated with their oxygen mobilities [42]. The oxygen mobility of the Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was varied to study its effect on the catalytic activity. From the above experimental results, the oxygen mobility of the catalyst was successfully modified without changing the texture of the catalyst (Figs. 1 and 4, Table 1 and Table 2). As reported previously, in addition to their textual properties and oxygen mobilities, the surface acidity/basicity and redox properties also affected the performance of the catalysts in this catalytic system [18,19,23]. Since no drastic changes were observed in the acidity and redox properties of the modified catalysts (Fig. S9 and Fig. S10), the disparities in performances shown in Fig. 6 must be almost exclusively due to the differences in the oxygen mobilities of the catalysts. The relationship between the binding energy of type II oxygen and the TOF is summarized in Fig. 8 . There was a linear relationship between the two, indicating that the activity of the catalysts increased with increasing oxygen mobility. Furthermore, we have compared the relationship between the oxygen mobilities of the catalysts and their CO2 conversion abilities (The oxygen mobility modification has little effect on the 1-butene conversion abilities of the catalysts). It was found that the CO2 conversion increased with increasing oxygen mobility (Table 2 and Fig. 6). This was consistent with the CO2 adsorption abilities of the catalysts as characterized by CO2-TPD (Fig. 5). All of these results indicated that the oxygen mobility played a key role in CO2 activation, which in turn enhanced the catalytic performance of the catalysts. 4.2 Proposed reaction mechanism Liu et al. reported that the reaction followed the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, but there was no experimental or computational data to support this conclusion [19]. However, ODH reactions using CO2 as a mild oxidant (such as the ODH of propane to propene, the ODH of butane to butane, and the ODH of ethylbenzene to styrene) have been studied extensively, and the reactions are generally considered to proceed by two routes: namely, one-step and two-step pathways [2,43]. In the one-step pathway, the alkane/alkene was oxidized to the alkene with CO2 through a direct interaction between CO2 and the alkane/alkene [43]. In the two-step pathway, the alkane/alkene was first dehydrogenated to the alkene with concomitant formation of H2, and then CO2 reacted with the H2 via the reverse water-gas shift reaction [43]. In the reaction containing 1-butene and CO2 for BD synthesis on γ-Al2O3-supported Fe-based metal oxide catalysts, there also existed two pathways, shown in Fig. 9 . In both pathways, the activation of CO2 by the catalyst is key to the reaction. An ODH of alkanes to alkenes with CO2 as a soft oxidant over metal oxides was reported by Reddy et al [2]. It was shown that the lattice oxygen in the metal oxides participated in H2 abstraction to form water, and the CO2 was responsible for maintaining the supply of lattice oxygen. According to this mechanism, the ODH of 1-butene to BD with CO2 could occur over Fe2O3, and the reaction pathway is described in Fig. 10 . The lattice oxygen in the Fe2O3 abstracted the α-hydrogen atom of 1-butene to form H2O and BD. At the same time, oxygen vacancies were produced in the Fe2O3, which were recovered through oxidation by the soft oxidant, CO2, with concomitant formation of CO. However, the experimental results shown in Fig. 7 indicated that BD synthesis was difficult on the single active component Fe2O3. Compared with Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3, the low catalytic activities observed over Fe2O3/MCM-41, Fe2O3/HY and FeVCrOX demonstrated that the γ-Al2O3 support and its Lewis acid sites were necessary for the reaction. As reported, simple dehydrogenation reactions could proceed over Al2O3 [1]. The Lewis acids sites on Al2O3 adsorbed alkenes and were responsible for the activation of the substrate, whereas the basic sites on Al2O3 abstracted the α-hydrogen atoms from the alkenes. For the ODH reaction with CO2, a different site was required for CO2 activation [1]. This was consistent with the above experimental results that γ-Al2O3 alone exhibited poor catalytic activity in the synthesis of BD via the ODH of 1-butene using CO2 as a soft oxidant, and a metal oxide is needed for the reaction. In addition, we have proved that the oxygen mobility of γ-Al2O3-supported metal oxide catalysts is the key to the activation of CO2. Thus, the reaction mechanism of the CO2-mediated ODH of 1-butene was proposed and is shown in Fig. 11 . First, 1-butene was absorbed and activated by the Lewis acid sites on γ-Al2O3. The α-hydrogen atom of 1-butene was then abstracted by the basic sites of γ-Al2O3 with formation of the carbanion. Then, another hydrogen of 1-butene was abstracted by the lattice oxygen and target product BD was formed with concomitant formation of H2O, and the oxygen vacancy was formed as a consequence. Then, CO2 was absorbed at the oxygen vacancy of the metal oxide. Oxidation by soft oxidant CO2 recovered the oxygen vacancy and generated CO. The reaction followed this cycle. 5 Conclusions A high-efficiency iron-based catalyst for the ODH of 1-butene with CO2 as a soft oxidant was prepared by designing a catalyst with high oxygen mobility. The TOF could reach 0.0035 molBD/molFe/s over the FeVCrOX/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, which was more than thrice that of the traditional Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. There was a linear relationship between the catalytic activity of catalysts and their oxygen mobility. The oxygen mobility plays an important role in CO2 activation, and thus was beneficial for the ODH reaction. Not only the lattice oxygens in the catalysts but also the Lewis acid sits on the γ-Al2O3 surface were required for the reaction to proceed. Based on the experimental results, the reaction mechanism was proposed, which will guide the building of efficient catalysts in the future. coredata.dc:description: The utilization of CO2 as a soft oxidant for the synthesis of 1,3-butadiene (BD) through the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of 1-butene is emerging as a potential technology not only because it can reduce the environmental problems caused by CO2 but also because of the abundant availability, low cost and mild oxidizing properties of CO2. However, this technology suffers from low catalytic activities due to the inherent inertness of CO2. Herein, a high-efficiency iron-based catalyst for the ODH of 1-butene with CO2 was designed and prepared from the perspective of improving the catalyst oxygen mobility, and the turnover frequency (TOF) has been improved to thrice that of the traditional Fe2O3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Furthermore, the effect of the oxygen mobility in the catalysts on their catalytic activity was determined. The oxygen mobility of the catalysts played a key role in CO2 activation, which in turn facilitated the ODH reaction. The TOFs of the catalysts increased linearly with increasing oxygen mobility. In addition, the γ-Al2O3 support, especially the Lewis acid sites on its surface, was proved to be necessary for the reaction. Both the carrier and active component were required for the reaction to proceed. Based on the above results, the mechanism of the ODH of 1-butene with CO2 was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Constructing a high-efficiency iron-based catalyst for carbon dioxide oxidative dehydrogenation of 1-butene: The role of oxygen mobility and proposed reaction mechanism
